title: How riots punishment system can mentally hurt people
body:
Riots system of zero tolerance to negativity is not only wrong in a moral sense but can also mentally damage people. You are not allowed to defend yourself in chat if you are getting flamed and that is a problem. You don’t always need to defend yourself and most of the time you can mute and move on but if someone starts threading you or your family or is wishing bad things on your family you need to be able to defend yourself in chat. 

I’m gonna compete this issue to an issue I had throughout middle school and high school.

In middle school I was bullied by one person non-stop but I couldn’t defend myself because my school didn’t allow that, they also didn’t do anything about the bully as they said that “it does not concern them”, this unfortunately hurt me mentally for years. Eventually I went to a therapist and she helped me through my problems but she told me that my issues stemmed from the fact that I would not stand up for myself due to the fact that I was not allowed to defend myself against my bully in middle school. 

Not being able to stand up for yourself or standing up for yourself and getting punished is bad for you mentally and can hurt you in the future. Riot needs to update their punishment system to take things into context and allow us to defend ourselves without getting punished.

You say that muting feels like giving up a lot in this thread, so I figured I'd do a basic reply to this thread rather than any of those posts in particular.

It seems to me that you see muting as a last resort, the thing you do when all else fails. That's why it feels bad to use it, because it's the acknowledgement that all else **has** failed, and therefore indirectly it feels like an acknowledgment of your own failure.

But that's just one way to see it. The other way to see it is as a tool of absolute control. It gives you 100% of the control of the situation. Whatever you say, you don't know what they will reply. Maybe they are able to use your own words against you, maybe they will feel like **they** need to stand up for what **they** have said and merely escalate the entire thing.

But there is absolutely nothing they can do about you muting them.

Let me share a little story from the time I played WoW: To spare you the convoluted story, some stranger thought I had been unfriendly to them, but I was literally unable to help them due to their own mistake. I even tried to do the exact thing they expected me to do.

And yet, the player just **snapped**. They started insulting me like crazy... and I blocked them.
Shortly thereafter I was messaged by *another* character about why the fuck I blocked him, and how I was a coward... so I blocked them.
This repeated a **lot**. I'm fairly sure that person went through all their existent characters to insult me before stopping.

Now here's the thing: I tried to stand up for myself, explaining what really had happened, but that just fell on deaf ears. There was literally no reaction to that. But when I **blocked** that person? That riled them up more than anything I could have ever said to them. My goal when I blocked that person wasn't to win. It was to remove the white noise of having somebody spam your chat with insults. But at the end of the day, blocking made me win:
I had absolute control over every step in the "fight", I was evidently more content with the situation and more calm, and I can't help but imagine I was happier about the outcome.

Being muted means you lose control. Muting gives you control.
It is not weak, it is not giving up, it is using the tools you have at your disposal to best protect yourself and your mental health.
And while it's probably not super healthy to try and get revenge on people: It makes a lot of people **really** mad when you mute them.

You are permitted to defend yourself with the mute button, which acts as a magic shield to prevent toxicity.

Last I checked, that doesn’t exist in real life for someone punching you.

Other than the mute button, you are allowed to stand up for yourself - provided what you say isn't inflammatory, or along the lines of what they're presumably saying to you.

However, I will stress: for the sake of the game, say your piece, mute them, and focus on your gameplay. Let them continue to screw themselves over, and your team will almost certainly take note of who's still playing, and who's too tilted to function.

Continued responses to the same garbage over and over again is a waste of time. Make your statement, mute them and let the kid have their aneurism, and do what you came to do - play some LoL.

To be fair...that's classic toxic masculinity. Often times, that's exactly the way people attempt to make a victim feel - like they should've done more, fought back, or never allowed it to get that far in the first place. I know where the guy is coming from.

The issue is more of a line that needs to be drawn. I get that muting people can feel like crap. I had my main perma'd from the time where I lived and died by OP's current logic.

That's why I say, you have plenty of ability to defend yourself - as long as you defend yourself with class. I just said I wasn't going to do this...but I'll give you at least one example.

A few weeks ago, our jungler (a cheeky guy) dove our bot tower at lv 2 against Draven/Thresh. Obviously, this resulted in his death, because you don't dive those two that early and expect anything less. He spent the next 27 minutes screaming at my adc (and presumably me, though I muted him after about 2...) about how we never helped him, we threw the whole game by not helping him, a few things about our stats (coming from a XinZhao self-proclaimed "one trick" with a 37%WR, I really couldn't care less...)
What I remember most clearly was the 2 points in which I muted him...

But the gist of the conversation was that I clearly told him "Yeah, you just lv 2 dove a Thresh with no minions at tower..." and he started presumably foaming at the mouth cause he made like 17 sentences in 20s that basically made no sense. It came out to something like "you %%%king idiots just gave up a double kill and now he has my red!" and something about how "people like [me and my adc] need more bleach" or something. So..."Honest Confusion and Concern" (not really) I asked him if he was ok, and said that if he needed me to, I could roam with him til he could play the game. (Note: this is a very nice, not at all inflammatory way of telling your jungler that you can hold his hand and babysit him for the whole game, because he has no skill)

He kept going on and on and on about the same crap. So after about 2 minutes (and him inting in the enemy's red side jungle instead of even pathing to his blue first) I just reiterated "You ran in lv 2 and turret dove a thresh. NOBODY could have helped you there. Muted/reported." and that was that...for me. He kept screaming at the adc

> Me muting someone gives me the feeling of giving up or giving in to the other person. I want to get them to stop what they are doing and admit they are wrong, even if that means being toxic in response.

Well, you're going to have to move past that mentality. Even in the real world, there's gonna be situations where you can't "stand up for yourself" by fighting back. And, beyond that, you need to learn that, in dealing with flamers, _being toxic back isn't going to help. It isn't going to make them stop, and it sure as hell isn't going to make them admit they're wrong._

_They are **flamers.** They don't care what you think, they're going to think that they're right, no matter how much toxicity you throw back at them. In fact, **being toxic back is just going to put them further on the defense, and they're not gonna want to apologize or stop when you're being just as bad as they are back.**_

You need to learn that retaliating and being toxic back is completely and utterly counter-intuitive. You need to learn to move past that self-imposed sense of defeat. 'Cause the rules of League aren't going to let you counterflame, and the mute button is your best response to a flamer - whether you like it or not.

Its like if a girl is raped, and people tell her to stop dressing provocatively.

In both cases, youre ignoring the problem. No girl should be raped, and the original thread was stating that the current punishment system treats the intiial aggressors no worse than the retaliators, who try to defend themselves (albeit often times as aggressively or more so).  

Drasticly different cmparison in regards to seriousmess? For sure. But i do hope you see the relation.

People who initiate should have more severe penalties imo (so long as their aggressiveness is equal...for instance, no racial slurs or hate speech), and should be made examples of. This community is getting worse and worse in chat. Its rather disconcerting, and ive begun using mute all (pings included, because now ping harassment is a thing) - when a year ago, i didnt feel a need.

Do not, DO NOT be that person who equates anything League of Legends to rape. Just fucking don't. That's a shit analogy to use in any situation, it's inflammatory, crass, and makes light of victims of something extremely serious.

Inflammatory? crass? making light of something..? 
Culture is always serious. It's what breeds our future. Using extreme situations is exactly how people can look at something seemingly minor, and draw comparisons to consequences on a larger scale.

> I dont understand. The guy is talking about the system, and i keep seeing comments like this targetting him.

They may be talking about the system, but the core of their problem is their attitude being incompatible with the system and the rules of League.

Retaliators are treated in the same capacity as the initial aggressors because _both players make the game that much worse for everyone else involved._ It's not just a flamer and a counterflamer in a vacuum; they're on teams with at least one to three other people, and those other people have to deal with _two_ flamers who'd rather shell out insults than play the game.

And, as mentioned previously, the core of the problem here is not with the system, it's the OP's self-imposed need to rise to every act of aggression, their single-minded imposition that _they have to make it stop through their own words and actions_, rather than apply actual, surefire solutions.

> Its like if a girl is raped, and people tell her to stop dressing provocatively.

This is a poor comparison. We're not telling the OP to "stop doing things that people will flame you for", we're telling them that _fighting back doesn't help, and that they need to learn to use the tools at their disposal rather than answer every toxic player in kind._

You're trying to compare apples to oranges here.

> But i do hope you see the relation.

The only relation between apples and oranges is that they're both fruit. Likewise, the only relation between the two presented scenarios is that something bad happens to someone. Other than that, the scenarios are incomparables.

>You're trying to compare apples to oranges here.

Let's not exaggerate. It's basically apples to VY Canis Majoris, the largest known star in the universe.

False. **Flaming them back** is not allowed, but actually defending yourself (read: Stating that you did or did not do something they said you didn't/did, or something along those lines) is.

You can go farther than that, with some tact. As long as what you're saying cannot be considered openly inflammatory (meaning, it's not something overly passive-aggressive, or counter-aggressive...something only the tilted, inflammatory individual would see as upsetting, because they're tilted and ruining everyone's game) you can get away with a lot.

I'm a support main...I can give you some examples. But I believe I won't...because then everyone's going to see me as the devil's advocate for being a low-key douche to everyone who looks at me funny. :P
Of course there's more you can get away with, but it's a harder distinction to make, especially with people who you're already having to explain the difference between flaming and defending yourself.

The last bit is purely false, though. As long as you are not repeating zero-tolerance words or phrases, and not flaming, responding won't get you punished. "I didn't say anything like that" is not punished.

There is nothing you can say in chat to defend yourself from a threat or wishes of harm. If you think any of those threats are credible, go to the police. Shrieking like a banshee in chat while you stand there and get executed by Gromp has no benefits of any kind, defensive or otherwise.

Bullying the bully isn't standing up for yourself.

You're simply becoming what you're fighting against. Riot's system is to get rid of the problem. Your case on how it hurts the mentality of toxic players and damages them, that's the least of Riot's concern. Players who use their chat to reflect back the negativity is the exact same as the players who are the initiators. 

The thing is, fighting the issues with the same tactic is exactly the exact same issue Riot and the community is fighting against. You're here to play a video game. If you choose to use the chat to "defend" yourself, then you're the very thing you hate. Two wrongs do not make a right. 

You're either part of the game or part of the problem. 

I'd not choose the latter on this one.
